data.title: Inserting tabs causes Code to stop responding.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.3
- OS Version: Windows 10 x64 Pro (build 10586)

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create a `.css` file.
2. Use `tab` inside CSS comments.

data.title: how to check command is completed or in progress via API
Intellisense doesn't work immediately for new .js file added via File -> New File (or Ctrl + N) but does for files added via Explorer
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.5.3 (5be4091987a98e3870d89d630eb87be6d9bafd27, 2016-09-22T08:50:42.185Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14393

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Install the Node typings for the current project
2. Create new JavaScript file (foo.js) by clicking on the New File button in Explorer
3. Enter the code  - var http = require('http) and then http.   (note the intellisense works correctly.
4. Create another new JavaScript file (bar.js) using the File -> New File (or Ctrl + N) option
5. Repeat step 2. above.  There is no intellisense.
6. Close and then reopen bar.js.  Intellisense now works for bar.js

data.title: (Suggestion on syntax highlighting) Offer a setting for comments to appear in italics
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.3
- OS Version: win10 x64

My suggestion on syntax highlighting is offer a setting ( in Preferences|User Settings.) 
for comments to appear in _italics_.

It's a feature I've noticed in Atom's default theme and I like it a lot, 
so I've modified Sublime Text's default color scheme (Monokai) to also show comments in italics. 
It helps the user focus on the actual code better, visually ignoring the comments.

data.title: testing 13132
test
Add option for --list-extensions arg
data.body:
- Updates listExtensions() and getId() for optional params showVersions / withVersion
- Adds --help info for new option

Resolves: #12963

data.title: No intellisense in project.json from local nuget source
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Any
- OS Version: Any

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create a lib and compile (dotnet new -t library)
2. "dotnet pack" it
3. Create a Nuget.config with a local file repository
4. "nuget add" the library to this repository
5. Create an empty .NET app (dotnet new)
6. Attempt to use the library by adding the library name and version to project.json

No intellisense in proect.json. However, if you add the library manually, it will be added to the "dotnet restore" and work.

4. open devtool, you can see some error

data.title: Terminal window *incredibly* slow.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.3
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open up VS Code.
2. Use the Terminal window by typing something in.

I never really noticed too much but with the latest versions of Code and Ionide (which use the Terminal window now for F# output), I've noticed that the Terminal window is really, really slow - not just for output sent to the terminal from F# but also just typing in the standard terminal - long pauses (1/2 seconds) before it "catches up" with what I'm typing etc.. It also blocks the main editor window whilst these pauses happen.

I suppose that this could be any number of things - happy to help provide more details that would help.

data.title: TypeScript decorators not recognized
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.3
- OS Version: Ubuntu 16.04

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Install [angular-cli](https://github.com/angular/angular-cli)
2. Run ng new myproject
3. Create a new service: cd myproject && ng g service myservice
4. Open the generated project in VSCode and open the myservice.service.ts file

Decorated service not recognized (see img, two examples of decorators not recognized: @Injectable and @Inject)

![not recognized](http://pix.toile-libre.org/upload/original/1475345638.png) 

Check list:
1. "experimentalDecorators": true in tsconfig.json

data.title: Icons seem blurry
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.3
- OS Version: Win10

All the file-icon extensions that I've tried have their icons shown blurry.
Not sure why, but I guess it has something to do with VS Code itself and its HTML (I would guess you scale the image or something).

Example:

VS Code:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8676903/19016106/b9547da4-8819-11e6-8e7a-d0af8cfcaab9.png)

Brackets (could well be the exact same icon only mirrored, although I am not sure):
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8676903/19016109/c862bf68-8819-11e6-8771-f302bfaa22f0.png)

Anyhow, I have tried all icons I could find and they all look as bad as that.

(While we are comparing the two, I like the font Bracket uses too - not sure where they got it... I like many things on VS Code as well. Just pointing out where you could probably improve.)

There are some icons that look a bit better:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8676903/19016236/f20cbb9a-881c-11e6-9592-b0b6e657e4e6.png)

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8676903/19016241/0d7a08e2-881d-11e6-8ceb-41dd030b1dfa.png)

Things are improving a bit when not using a zoom:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8676903/19016256/84a1db70-881d-11e6-8f1c-a65874edf903.png)

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8676903/19016269/deddbce4-881d-11e6-802f-526b089dda14.png)

You can only see no problem with the "Minimal (Visual Studio Code)" extension :

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8676903/19016293/595a622e-881e-11e6-9f9d-1ada7ebd2acf.png)

But if you use zoom, even this gets blurry:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8676903/19016310/afa4e762-881e-11e6-81bb-33bf897fc968.png)

Maybe I want too much. :(

data.title: TypeScript declaration files for Jasmine not found in Angular 2 project
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.3
- OS Version: Ubuntu 16.04

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Install [angular-cli](https://github.com/angular/angular-cli)
2. Run ng new myproject
3. Open the created project with VSCode, and open the spec file (src/app/app.component.spec.ts)

Functions like describe, beforeEach, it and expect are not recognized (see img)

![Jasmine ts types not found](http://pix.toile-libre.org/upload/original/1475345018.png)

Check list:
- node_modules/@types/jasmine/index.d.ts file exist
- this option is included in tsconfig.json

```
"typeRoots": [
      "../node_modules/@types"
    ]
```

As tsd is officially deprecated since August and I'm using the last VSCode release, what could be happening?

data.title: Request for features
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.3
- OS Version: Win10
1. I think we should be able to disable extensions without uninstalling them.
2. I see no obvious way to ignore files on Git. Brackets has an obvious option that is extremely easy to find. Maybe I miss something here?
3. I see no obvious way to clone repos from VSCode. I think it should be able to do this.
4. I can't find a good way to adjust the font size globally (not only in the editor). The best I found was this while trying to make fonts look more like Brackets and I don't like it much:
   "window.zoomLevel": -0.3,
   "editor.fontFamily": "arial, sans-serif"
5. All the file-icon extensions that I tried have their icon blurry. Not sure why, but I guess it has to do something with VSCode itself and its HTML.
6. Maybe the "button" for running the build tasks (and maybe also running the code) should be in a more accessible place?
7. I see no way to view the history with Git.

data.title: Git "Clean All" feature should display a confirmation dialog
data.body:
The Git "Clean All" action is destructive and unlike other actions, can't be undone. The user might end up loosing his/her work by firing it without previous knowledge of this or even by accident. I suggest that when the user click on it, the editor display a confirmation dialog allowing him/her to cancel the action if done by mistake or if unsure of the consequences.
- VSCode Version: 1.5.3
- OS Version: OS X 10.11.6

data.title: Not recognising Typescript 2.0 npm/@types definitions in code highlighting
data.body:
I have been using the Typescript 2.0 approach to definition files and installed them, but VSCode doesn't seem to be picking these up, see the unrecognised modules, and the definitions in `node_modules/@types` on the right-hand side. `tsc` runs fine. I have reopened Code a few times to see if this is intermittent. It would appear to be persistent. 

[![enter image description here](http://i.stack.imgur.com/dAchZ.png)](http://i.stack.imgur.com/dAchZ.png)
- VSCode Version: **1.5.3**
- OS Version: **Windows 10 Pro**
- Node: **6.7.0**

Steps to Reproduce:
1. `git clone https://github.com/georgeedwards/docs`
2. `npm i`
3. `code .`
4. Observe Highlighting issues

data.title: Automatic bug fix suggestions
data.body:
- VSCode Version:
- OS Version:

I would like to propose Auto bug fix, which when turned on would capture the error from console.error or console output, make a search on stackoverflow for accepted answers to the problem and display it in a window/pane in VSC.

data.title: That is not possible to copy information from Problems window
data.body:
The Problems window does not allow to copy information about detected problems:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/14539/19013409/1c10d40a-87d0-11e6-958c-200a162ddff9.png)
- VSCode Version: 1.6.0-insider (1.6.0-insider)
- OS Version: Mac OS X 10.11.6 (15G1004)

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open a source code - here C# code - with any kind of error or warning 
2. Open View > Problems
3. Try to select with mouse or using keyboard
4. Try to copy selected text with mouse or keyboard

Expected:
I should be able to copy selected warning/error text in any way (keyboard or mouse)

Actual:
I'm not able to copy selected warning/error text in any way

That's not a problem with my own code, but sometimes I have to pass just the information about the problem to other people.

Thanks!

data.title: Bundled icon theme should be a Visual Studio icon theme

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body: VS Code shares a lot of design with Visual Studio, which looks awesome. I think the default, bundled icon theme should be a Visual Studio icon theme. The nomo theme comes pretty close: https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=be5invis.vscode-icontheme-nomo-dark

data.title: Intellisense doesn't update on tsconfig.json setting changing
data.body:
I have installing typesciprt@2.1.0-dev.20160927 by npm in my project.

After I change tsconfig.json setting like adding or removing "dom" in compilerOptions.lib, I need to restart VS Code for updating the Intellisense system.

Is there any hot key or method to refresh the Intellisense instantly after I set tsconfig.json to avoid restart VS Code application?

Thanks. 
- VSCode Version: 1.5.3
- OS Version: Windows 7 64bits SP1

data.title: [Question]Disable extensions is not working anymore in Windows?
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.3 and 1.6.0-insider
- OS Version: Windows 10

-- Sorry for the English, I used Google Translator --

Disable extensions with `--disable-extensions` is not working anymore in Windows?

Now I need to relocate the extensions folder or rename to be able to disable, as said @joaomoreno  this [comment](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/8926#issuecomment-231664050)? --disable-extension is faster.

data.title: Cannot disable syntax highlighter
data.body:

2. Start making some edits
3. I'm seeing a syntax highlight window open up and I can't find a single setting for editor to disable it.  Is there  a setting already for this? This really irks when writing code and the popup blocks code I'm trying to reference.  Screenshot attached to this issue.

data.title: Logo above watermark commands animates every time it becomes visible
data.body:
If I have one editor open, then close it, the vscode logo does the slide up animation. Is this by design? Maybe, but I thought maybe it's only supposed to happen the first time or something.
![sep-30-2016 18-31-57](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/323878/19010930/44984972-873e-11e6-899a-fa1272e8040b.gif)
